element.summary: In Phase 2: Understand, young people will research and conduct interviews in order to more deeply understand their chosen injustice. facilitator.about: High Resolves is a recognized leader in the design and delivery of citizenship and leadership learning experiences. Since our inception in 2005, our award-winning program has engaged over 200,000 high school students in Australia and is growing fast on a fully self-funding basis. We have expanded offshore to the United States thanks to the generous support of Omidyar Network and the Einhorn Family Charitable Trust and have begun further expansion into China and Canada, with new partnerships also forming in Brazil and Africa.
facilitator.name: High Resolves

entity.summary: In this lesson, students understand how human rights can help society. They begin the lesson identifying the difference between things people want and deserve. Students explore the definition of human rights and the challenges in determining what is right for everyone. The class works together to create a declaration of rights and reflect on the potential reasons why rights can sometimes not transfer from paper to reality. Students examine how rights can help people and wider society and compare the 30 articles of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights to the list they created. The lesson concludes with students reflecting on the responsibility we all have to ensure our own everyday actions reflect human rights.
entity.title: Human Rights

facilitator.about: High Resolves is a recognized leader in the design and delivery of citizenship and leadership learning experiences. Since our inception in 2005, our award-winning program has engaged over 200,000 high school students in Australia and is growing fast on a fully self-funding basis. We have expanded offshore to the United States thanks to the generous support of Omidyar Network and the Einhorn Family Charitable Trust and have begun further expansion into China and Canada, with new partnerships also forming in Brazil and Africa.
facilitator.name: High Resolves

entity.summary: In this lesson, students understand how human rights can help society. They begin the lesson identifying the difference between things people want and deserve. Students explore the definition of human rights and the challenges in determining what is right for everyone. The class works together to create a declaration of rights and reflect on the potential reasons why rights can sometimes not transfer from paper to reality. Students examine how rights can help people and wider society and compare the 30 articles of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights to the list they created. The lesson concludes with students reflecting on the responsibility we all have to ensure our own everyday actions reflect human rights.

element.summary: In Phase 2: Understand, young people will research and conduct interviews in order to more deeply understand their chosen injustice. element.summary: In Phase 1: Choose, the young people will go through 6 tools in order to identify an injustice in their community. You will begin by introducing the peacemakers to the Peace First program through the introductory video. The young people will then reflect on their role as peacemakers and create group norms which will guide them through their work. They will then identify positive and negative aspects of their community and determine what is an injustice versus an inconvenience. By voting, young people will decide which injustice in their community they would like to address for their peacemaking project.

element.summary: In Phase 1: Choose, the young people will go through 6 tools in order to identify an injustice in their community. You will begin by introducing the peacemakers to the Peace First program through the introductory video. The young people will then reflect on their role as peacemakers and create group norms which will guide them through their work. They will then identify positive and negative aspects of their community and determine what is an injustice versus an inconvenience. By voting, young people will decide which injustice in their community they would like to address for their peacemaking project.

facilitator.about: High Resolves is a recognized leader in the design and delivery of citizenship and leadership learning experiences. Since our inception in 2005, our award-winning program has engaged over 200,000 high school students in Australia and is growing fast on a fully self-funding basis. We have expanded offshore to the United States thanks to the generous support of Omidyar Network and the Einhorn Family Charitable Trust and have begun further expansion into China and Canada, with new partnerships also forming in Brazil and Africa.
facilitator.name: High Resolves

provider.about: High Resolves is a recognized leader in the design and delivery of citizenship and leadership learning experiences. provider.name: High Resolves

entity.summary: In this lesson, students understand how human rights can help society. They begin the lesson identifying the difference between things people want and deserve. Students explore the definition of human rights and the challenges in determining what is right for everyone. The class works together to create a declaration of rights and reflect on the potential reasons why rights can sometimes not transfer from paper to reality. Students examine how rights can help people and wider society and compare the 30 articles of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights to the list they created. The lesson concludes with students reflecting on the responsibility we all have to ensure our own everyday actions reflect human rights.
entity.title: Human Rights

facilitator.about: High Resolves is a recognized leader in the design and delivery of citizenship and leadership learning experiences. Since our inception in 2005, our award-winning program has engaged over 200,000 high school students in Australia and is growing fast on a fully self-funding basis. We have expanded offshore to the United States thanks to the generous support of Omidyar Network and the Einhorn Family Charitable Trust and have begun further expansion into China and Canada, with new partnerships also forming in Brazil and Africa.

element.summary: In Phase 2: Understand, young people will research and conduct interviews in order to more deeply understand their chosen injustice. They will begin by interviewing members of the community who may have opposing views. The young people will then create problem and solution trees to uncover the root cause of the injustice and brainstorm solutions. Once they have identified potential solutions they will identify any potential risks for this project.
element.title: Phase 2: Understanding the Injustice

element.summary: In Phase 1: Choose, the young people will go through 6 tools in order to identify an injustice in their community. You will begin by introducing the peacemakers to the Peace First program through the introductory video. The young people will then reflect on their role as peacemakers and create group norms which will guide them through their work. They will then identify positive and negative aspects of their community and determine what is an injustice versus an inconvenience. By voting, young people will decide which injustice in their community they would like to address for their peacemaking project.

facilitator.about: High Resolves is a recognized leader in the design and delivery of citizenship and leadership learning experiences. Since our inception in 2005, our award-winning program has engaged over 200,000 high school students in Australia and is growing fast on a fully self-funding basis. We have expanded offshore to the United States thanks to the generous support of Omidyar Network and the Einhorn Family Charitable Trust and have begun further expansion into China and Canada, with new partnerships also forming in Brazil and Africa.

entity.summary: In this lesson, students understand how human rights can help society. They begin the lesson identifying the difference between things people want and deserve. Students explore the definition of human rights and the challenges in determining what is right for everyone. The class works together to create a declaration of rights and reflect on the potential reasons why rights can sometimes not transfer from paper to reality. Students examine how rights can help people and wider society and compare the 30 articles of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights to the list they created. The lesson concludes with students reflecting on the responsibility we all have to ensure our own everyday actions reflect human rights.
entity.title: Human Rights

We have expanded offshore to the United States thanks to the generous support of Omidyar Network and the Einhorn Family Charitable Trust and have begun further expansion into China and Canada, with new partnerships also forming in Brazil and Africa.

entity.summary: In this lesson, students understand how human rights can help society. They begin the lesson identifying the difference between things people want and deserve. Students explore the definition of human rights and the challenges in determining what is right for everyone. The class works together to create a declaration of rights and reflect on the potential reasons why rights can sometimes not transfer from paper to reality. Students examine how rights can help people and wider society and compare the 30 articles of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights to the list they created. The lesson concludes with students reflecting on the responsibility we all have to ensure our own everyday actions reflect human rights.
entity.title: Human Rights

element.summary: In Phase 2: Understand, young people will research and conduct interviews in order to more deeply understand their chosen injustice. They will begin by interviewing members of the community who may have opposing views. The young people will then create problem and solution trees to uncover the root cause of the injustice and brainstorm solutions. Once they have identified potential solutions they will identify any potential risks for this project.
element.title: Phase 2: Understanding the Injustice

element.summary: In Phase 1: Choose, the young people will go through 6 tools in order to identify an injustice in their community. You will begin by introducing the peacemakers to the Peace First program through the introductory video. The young people will then reflect on their role as peacemakers and create group norms which will guide them through their work. They will then identify positive and negative aspects of their community and determine what is an injustice versus an inconvenience. By voting, young people will decide which injustice in their community they would like to address for their peacemaking project.
element.title: Phase 1: Choosing an Injustice

entity.summary: In this lesson, students understand how human rights can help society. They begin the lesson identifying the difference between things people want and deserve. Students explore the definition of human rights and the challenges in determining what is right for everyone. The class works together to create a declaration of rights and reflect on the potential reasons why rights can sometimes not transfer from paper to reality. Students examine how rights can help people and wider society and compare the 30 articles of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights to the list they created. The lesson concludes with students reflecting on the responsibility we all have to ensure our own everyday actions reflect human rights.
entity.title: Human Rights

element.summary: In Phase 2: Understand, young people will research and conduct interviews in order to more deeply understand their chosen injustice. They will begin by interviewing members of the community who may have opposing views. The young people will then create problem and solution trees to uncover the root cause of the injustice and brainstorm solutions. Once they have identified potential solutions they will identify any potential risks for this project.

entity.summary: In this lesson, students understand how human rights can help society. They begin the lesson identifying the difference between things people want and deserve. Students explore the definition of human rights and the challenges in determining what is right for everyone. The class works together to create a declaration of rights and reflect on the potential reasons why rights can sometimes not transfer from paper to reality. Students examine how rights can help people and wider society and compare the 30 articles of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights to the list they created. The lesson concludes with students reflecting on the responsibility we all have to ensure our own everyday actions reflect human rights.

facilitator.about: High Resolves is a recognized leader in the design and delivery of citizenship and leadership learning experiences. Since our inception in 2005, our award-winning program has engaged over 200,000 high school students in Australia and is growing fast on a fully self-funding basis. We have expanded offshore to the United States thanks to the generous support of Omidyar Network and the Einhorn Family Charitable Trust and have begun further expansion into China and Canada, with new partnerships also forming in Brazil and Africa.

entity.summary: In this lesson, students understand how human rights can help society. They begin the lesson identifying the difference between things people want and deserve. Students explore the definition of human rights and the challenges in determining what is right for everyone. The class works together to create a declaration of rights and reflect on the potential reasons why rights can sometimes not transfer from paper to reality. Students examine how rights can help people and wider society and compare the 30 articles of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights to the list they created. The lesson concludes with students reflecting on the responsibility we all have to ensure our own everyday actions reflect human rights.
entity.title: Human Rights

Since our inception in 2005, our award-winning program has engaged over 200,000 high school students in Australia and is growing fast on a fully self-funding basis. We have expanded offshore to the United States thanks to the generous support of Omidyar Network and the Einhorn Family Charitable Trust and have begun further expansion into China and Canada, with new partnerships also forming in Brazil and Africa.
provider.name: High Resolves

entity.summary: In this lesson, students understand how human rights can help society. They begin the lesson identifying the difference between things people want and deserve. Students explore the definition of human rights and the challenges in determining what is right for everyone. The class works together to create a declaration of rights and reflect on the potential reasons why rights can sometimes not transfer from paper to reality. Students examine how rights can help people and wider society and compare the 30 articles of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights to the list they created. The lesson concludes with students reflecting on the responsibility we all have to ensure our own everyday actions reflect human rights.
entity.title: Human Rights

element.summary: In Phase 2: Understand, young people will research and conduct interviews in order to more deeply understand their chosen injustice. They will begin by interviewing members of the community who may have opposing views. The young people will then create problem and solution trees to uncover the root cause of the injustice and brainstorm solutions. Once they have identified potential solutions they will identify any potential risks for this project.
element.title: Phase 2: Understanding the Injustice

facilitator.about:
Peace First is a non-profit organization dedicated to helping young people around the world to become powerful peacemakers by:

- Investing in their ideas
- Providing them with tools and skills
- Connecting them with other awesome young people around the world
- Sharing their stories and impact with the world

element.summary: In Phase 3: Plan, the young people will turn their insights into action and invite others to join them. They will begin by creating SMART goals and then identify resources needed to carry out the plan. The young people will create a budget for their project and identify people, with whom they could partner.
element.title: Phase 3: Planning to Solve the Injustice

element.summary: In Phase 4: Act, the young people will engage in their peacemaking projects. As the projects progress, teams can track their progress through a worksheet and online to stay accountable to the work. It is also a good time to go back to the team effectiveness survey and check in on progress.

element.summary: In Phase 5: Reflect, the young people will reflect on their journey as a peacemaking both individually and as a team. The young people will then plan a celebration and giving thanks activity for all of their hard work and the hard work of the community that supported them. Then a tool is for the peacemakers to tell their stories. The last tool includes a few questions for young people to reflect on their full journey.

element.summary: In Phase 1: Choose, the young people will go through 6 tools in order to identify an injustice in their community. You will begin by introducing the peacemakers to the Peace First program through the introductory video. The young people will then reflect on their role as peacemakers and create group norms which will guide them through their work. They will then identify positive and negative aspects of their community and determine what is an injustice versus an inconvenience. By voting, young people will decide which injustice in their community they would like to address for their peacemaking project.
element.title: Phase 1: Choosing an Injustice

We have expanded offshore to the United States thanks to the generous support of Omidyar Network and the Einhorn Family Charitable Trust and have begun further expansion into China and Canada, with new partnerships also forming in Brazil and Africa.
